name: Infosys
title: Dual AI Leadership with Central Platform Fabric

classification.classificationRationale: Infosys demonstrates M4 Hub-and-Spoke: central Topaz platform provides unified AI infrastructure (the hub) while multiple distributed labs and CoEs (Living Labs, London AI Lab, Cognition co-innovation labs, Cursor CoE) serve as spokes. The dual-leadership structure—Sunil Senan for AI strategy/capability, Bali DR for AI deployment/service lines—reflects hub-and-spoke coordination. Secondary M2 reflects strong CoE characteristics: standards, enablement, governance (ISO 42001 certification), tiered training (270K 'AI Aware' certifications). Not M6 Portfolio because there's clear central coordination through Topaz, not autonomous parallel experiments.

description:
Infosys structures AI through a hub-and-spoke model centered on its Topaz platform—a unified AI infrastructure comprising 12,000+ AI assets, 150+ pre-trained models, and 10+ specialized platforms. The hub provides standards, governance, and shared capability; the spokes include 12+ Living Labs globally, the London AI Lab (partnership with Cambridge), Cognition co-innovation labs (for Devin deployment), and specialized centers like the Cursor CoE.

AI leadership is distributed across two EVP-level roles rather than a single CAIO: Sunil Senan (Global Head of Data and AI) owns AI-first strategy and portfolio, while Balakrishna 'Bali' DR (EVP, AI and Industry Verticals) drives AI adoption across service lines and internal operations. This matrix structure—one leader for capability, one for deployment—enables scaling AI across a 324K workforce while maintaining strategic coherence.

The organization follows a deliberate three-wave adoption strategy: Wave 1 (Nov 2022-24 months) focused on pilots and productivity; Wave 2 (current) addresses IT operations and business processes; Wave 3 (next 6-12 months) targets process and experience improvement. This measured rollout is reflected in metrics: 4,600 active AI projects with 90% of top 200 clients, 28M lines of AI-generated code, 500+ agents built, and workforce transformation evidenced by 12,506 headcount reduction alongside 20K planned FY27 hires.

mechanisms.name: Consumer-Grade UX for Employee Tools
mechanisms.evidence: 270,000+ employees (84% of workforce) certified as 'AI Aware' suggests accessible, well-designed internal tools that achieve mass adoption. The Topaz platform's design for workforce-wide use indicates consumer-grade accessibility.

mechanisms.name: Deploy to Thousands Before You Know What Works
mechanisms.evidence: Three-wave strategy explicitly starts with 'pilots, productivity' (Wave 1) before scaling. However, the 28M lines of AI-generated code and 500+ agents built suggest rapid internal deployment. CEO Parekh's quote about 'real projects... being used at scale today' in financial services indicates large-scale deployment.

layers.label: Cursor AI Center of Excellence Partnership
layers.summary: Infosys partnered with Cursor (AI coding platform) to launch a Center of Excellence for AI-native software development on Jan 27, 2026. The CoE helps companies adopt AI coding agents and build AI-native products. Includes a demo space for clients to test Infosys' Topaz Fabric (cloud/data/AI platform). Cursor's AI coding tools being rolled out to Infosys developers worldwide. This is a dual-purpose CoE: client-facing capability building AND internal developer productivity transformation.

openQuestions: How does the Cursor CoE relate to Infosys's existing AI training programs (reported 250K employees trained on AI)?
What metrics is Infosys tracking? Cursor reports 39% increase in shipped PRs — is Infosys measuring similarly?
Is this primarily a marketing/sales partnership or a genuine structural transformation?
How does this compare to TCS, Wipro, Accenture AI augmentation approaches?
What is the internal org structure of the CoE? Dedicated team or distributed?
Exact reporting relationship between Sunil Senan and Bali DR - are they peers or is there hierarchy?
What percentage of the $500M innovation fund is allocated specifically to AI vs other initiatives?
Specific headcount for the Topaz team or AI-dedicated employees (as opposed to AI-trained)
taxonomyFeedback: At 100,000 engineers, this is the largest announced CoE by headcount. Scale may change the CoE dynamics — governance at 100K is different from governance at 100.
The dual purpose (internal enablement + client demo) blurs the line between CoE and product. The 'AI Engineering Experience Zone' is a sales tool.

[2026-02] Infosys exhibits an interesting 'matrix hub-and-spoke' variant: the hub is not a single team but rather a platform (Topaz) combined with dual leadership roles that split strategy from deployment. This may warrant discussion of whether M4 should recognize platform-as-hub versus team-as-hub structures.

[2026-02] The dual-leadership model (Senan for capability, Bali for deployment) represents a sophisticated organizational design for scaling AI across 324K employees. This contrasts with the single-CAIO model seen in many M4 specimens and may offer a template for very large enterprises where AI touches both internal operations and client delivery.

[2026-02] The workforce recomposition pattern—12,506 headcount reduction paired with 20K new hires—combined with 270K employees being AI-certified suggests a full-workforce transformation rather than isolated AI teams. This blurs the M4/M6 boundary: is it hub-and-spoke governance, or is it enterprise-wide adoption (M6a) with strong central coordination? The three-wave strategy's explicit phasing tips toward M4, but this edge case merits tracking.
